misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums only the even numbers. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each for evenness (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of the even values only, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Uses three double inputs rather than five integer inputs.
Computes (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds instead of summing even numbers.
Output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement or confusion between different assignment questions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the processing (loop + even check), and the desired output (sum of even numbers) and design your code around those requirements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the code (inputs, prompt, formula, and output message) matches an average acceleration problem and does not match any part of the given 'sum of even numbers' specification.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation using three double inputs, not a sum of even numbers over 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment entirely. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, the student wrote a program that calculates average acceleration from three velocity and time inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this assignment is asking them to calculate acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, rather than filtering and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (n % 2 == 0), and printing the sum of only those even numbers.
symptoms: Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of summing even numbers
Output is a single acceleration value instead of the sum of even numbers
Class name is 'AccelerationCalculator' instead of reflecting the even sum task
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read a different assignment, confused this assignment with another one, or did not carefully read the problem statement before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully: 'reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Use a loop to read 5 integers, check if each is even using the modulo operator (%), and accumulate the sum of even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics calculation) rather than the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Program reads 3 double values for an acceleration calculation instead of 5 integers for an even number sum

evidence.snippet:

        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);

Class name indicates this is an acceleration calculator, not an even number summer

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (implemented acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, instead of writing a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even numbers. The entire structure of the solution (inputs, processing, and output) corresponds to a different problem than the one assigned.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to read v0, v1, and t as doubles and compute the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integer values from the user, check each for evenness (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum as the final result.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for "Enter v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Reads three double values instead of five integers.
No loop to process 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
Calculates averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds instead of summing even numbers.
Output message is "The average acceleration is ..." rather than "Sum of even numbers: ...".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this question and a different assignment about computing average acceleration, or not carefully reading and translating the problem requirements into the correct input, processing, and output behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and outline the required inputs, processing steps, and outputs. For this task, list: (1) read 5 integers, (2) for each number, if it is even (n % 2 == 0) add it to a running sum, (3) after all 5 numbers, print the sum of the even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program—prompt text, variable names, formula, and printed message—matches a well-known acceleration exercise and does not include any elements of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration, with no handling of 5 integers, no even-checking condition, and no summation of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reading floating-point numbers instead of integers
misconceptions.description: The student used `nextDouble()` to read inputs, expecting floating-point numbers (doubles), whereas the required task was to read integers, which would typically use `nextInt()`. This is minor compared to the core problem but still indicates potential confusion in input handling based on data type requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading inputs using `nextDouble()` is appropriate for the data required, or perhaps they did not differentiate between integer and floating-point input methods.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To read an integer from standard input using Scanner, the programmer should use `nextInt()`. The problem explicitly asks for 5 integers.
symptoms: Use of nextDouble() when nextInt() is required by the original problem statement
misconceptions.root_cause: Mistake in implementation based on the current program (Acceleration Calculator) or lack of precise knowledge regarding Scanner methods for specific data types, if this code were to be adapted for Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure that the correct Scanner methods are used to match the expected data type, such as `nextInt()` for integer inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Evidence clearly shows the use of `nextDouble()` three times, which conflicts with the requirement of reading 5 integers for Q1.

evidence.note: Used nextDouble() for inputs, which is incorrect for a problem requiring integers (nextInt()).

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student has entirely misunderstood the assignment requirements. Instead of writing code to read 5 integers and sum the even numbers, the student wrote code to calculate physics-based acceleration from velocity and time inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment requires calculating acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum
Input prompt mentions 'v0, v1, and t' (physics terms) instead of requesting integers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student did not carefully read the problem statement and requirements before beginning coding. They appear to have worked on a completely different assignment (possibly a physics acceleration problem).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Loop through them, (3) Check if each is even using `n % 2 == 0`, (4) Accumulate the sum of even numbers, and (5) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with no overlap with the required logic (summing even numbers). This is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 physics parameters (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers for the even sum problem.

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
